Well, let me start from the beginning... I was baptised and raised Catholic, I didn't really have a choice in the matter. So now I'm almost 18 and I wonder, what does it mean to be Catholic? I have lots of questions. First, i'll tell you a little about myself just to cleara few things up becauseI know people tend tohave stereotypes in their mind when someone says "Oh, I'm Catholic." First of all I'm a democrat (okay, so I'm not 18, so it's not offical yet butit will be when I sign up to vote this coming fall) and so are both my parents. I am liberal when it comes to social issues, I support homosexual marriage, I'm pro choice, against the death penalty and against the war in Iraq. As far as fiscal issues go, I don't encourage military spending andI don't think we should have gone into Iraq in the first place but I do believe it is our job to clean up and do our best to help now that we are there. I do believe that wealthier people should pay more taxes, not less. I wouldn't encourage large amounts of spending to increase the deficit. I believe that money should be spent to benefit everyone, especially those in need (people who live in poverty, without health care, without money to buy food, to improve their quality of life)not to wealthyspecial interest groups just looking to benefit themselves. As far as foriegn affairs go, I think it's important to make alliances with other countries and work together to make decisions that benefit everyone instead of trying to be a hero and do everything ourselves. This isn't a game, it shouldn't be about winning or losing or power or money. We are all human beings, we are all equal. Perhaps that sounds silly or idealistic but if more people were more accomidating of others instead of just lookingto benefitthemselves this world would be a better place. I believe in preserving and protecting the environment andI am against nuclear weapons. I thinkthey only leads to troubleand power struggles between greedy countries. Perhaps that is not the detailed and organizeddescription that you would have wanted about my political belifs. AlthoughI understand the importants of politics and keeping up with currentevents and news to create my own opinions, I must say that I have always had a hard time doing so. I am not an expert on U.S. history, I do not read the business section, I can not tell you the order of our past presidents, or the names of ourCA senators, I do not like economics or enjoy the stock market but I do have opinions and I do care about people and how we treat each other and our planet. I am not yet 18 and I know I have a lot to learn. I look forward to gaining knowledge and responsibility and I will accept the challenge and do what I can to make this world a better place. Okay, so back to religion...I don't look down upon people who are not Catholic. I would never try to coerce someone into converting. I don't believe that people who arn't Christians willburn in hell.I respect other people's belifs even if I don't agree with them. I did not enjoy going to church when I was little, in fact I did just about everything I could to avoid it. I distinctly remember having conversations with a friend about how much we didn't like going to church because it was boring. Even now, I don't go to church every Sunday although I do enjoy going. There is always a good message behind each mass, talking about life and improving one's self. The priest doesn'ttry to present himselfto beany different than the rest of us.He treatsusas equals. None of us are perfect, but we come together to learn in a search for inner peace, satisfaction and happiness to share with everyone in our lives. We sing, we pray and we thank the Lord for all that we have been given. I am not familar with all of the stories in the Bible. I do not recite verses on a daily basis. I cannot tell you all the names of the diciples nor can I recite all ten commandments word for word. Does that mean I have failed? Does that mean I'm not Catholic? Some would probably say so but I believe that religion is not about whether you meet all the requirements or how much you pray each day, or what you know. I believe religion is a very personal matter, it's about what works for you. It is all about searching within yourself and learning to be a better person. Learning tobe grateful for what you have and give back to those who helped you and those who need help. It gives me hope, it gives me faith in a greater good in this crazy world. Church is not about being exclusive or elite, it's about people coming together to grow in love. Love for each other and love for God. It's about believing in a greater good and working together to make a difference. To help others, to help yourself. That is my opinion. Take it for what you will, perhaps you feel differently. I don't mean to say that being Catholic and going to church is the only way to achieve these goals, by no means is that true. There are many organizations and groups you can join, there are many other ways to go about doing the same thing. This is just one path, one that I happen to follow. I just wanted to get all that out there to clear things up for myself and so you know a little bit more about me and what my views are. Well, I think that's about it for now. Let me know what you think. Take care!

Have you ever wanted to love someone so much that it hurts? I have. You know, I've spent a lot of time lately thinking about what I want to do with my life, whatI want to accomplish and what I want to be remembered as. And ya know what? Above all, what I want for myself is to find a husband, a man to love, who truely loves me back. That's always been my dream, it's whatI long for, whatI really truely deeply wantin my heart,for me. I do a lot for other people,I am always ready tolisten, tohelp, tomake achange for the better in any wayI can. I get so muchsatisfaction out of helping others and making a difference. It feels so good tobring a smile to someone's face. Even just little things likesmiling,giving a compliment, saying 'thank you'or holding open a door make a big difference. Despite my desire to help others and do what is right, I can't help but want something for myself, to have as my own. Perhaps it is just my idealistic self that longs for something so pure and perfect as true love. Someargue that it doesn't evenexist, butI have hope. Some would say it is becauseI have yet to feel the pain of true heartbreak,perhaps they are right. Maybe I am just asking for heartache, but, so be it.I am willing to try. I feel like I have so much to give, I just need to find someone who wants it and wants to love me back.It may sound stupid or silly, or even selfish butI can't help it, that's howI feel. Of course there are other things I want to do but as they say, love conquers all. I cannot wait to fall in love, I hope it is as wonderful as I imagine it to be. I know this sounds premature and I know I may have a long way to go and there may be many guys in between but I believe I will get there someday. *sigh* I hope so... Other things I plan to do (just the big stuff): I want to finish college with honors and a good golf record. I want to join the Peace Corps and travel to 3rd world countries and use my aquired skills to make a difference in the lives of those less fortunate than myself. I want to find a job where I can find joy and satisfaction in my work, helping others and making a difference in the world. I don't need to make a lot of money, just enough to live comfortably with my family. I believe that too much money is dangerous, and uneccisary. I want to fall in love with a man, get married and live a few years on our own before we start a family (to make sure we can provide a solid foundation to raise a child). Honestly, the thought of parenting scares the heck out of me. I don't know if I can handle it. I don't know, it's hard to say right now, but if I do decide to have children I would seriously consider adoption because there are millions of children that need a loving home and I would be honored and humbled to take one (or more) into my family. Well, that's about as far as i've gotten with my future. I think that's pretty good, don't cha think? =P That's about allI have to say for now. TTYL

Love your neighbor as you would yourself. That is a quote from church this morning. I really enjoyed church today, it was all about learning to love your neighbor and giving without asking to receive. We read the story of the good Samaritan who stops to help a man who was beaten and left for dead on the side of the road after the man was ignored by the first two passer-byes. He cleaned the man's wounds and took him to an Inn and paid for the Inn keeper to take care of him without asking for anything in return. Giving without asking for reciprocation...one of those lessons that's easy to learn but difficult to carry out.
